CARDIAC_FAILURE.definition: Pediatric heart failure is the inability of the heart to maintain adequate circulation for the metabolic needs of the growing body, leading to pulmonary, systemic, or both types of congestion.

etiopathogenesis.neonates: Critical congenital heart disease (e.g., HLHS, TAPVC)
etiopathogenesis.infants: Large VSD, PDA, AV canal defect
etiopathogenesis.older_children: Rheumatic heart disease (mitral/aortic valve lesions), cardiomyopathy

investigations.purpose: Mainstay – EF, structural defects, pericardial effusion

pharmacologic_therapy.role: In selected patients with poor LV function

treat_underlying_cause: Antibiotics for rheumatic fever or myocarditis

ATRIAL_SEPTAL_DEFECT.definition: A congenital heart defect characterized by a persistent opening in the interatrial septum, causing a left-to-right shunt.

types.details: Most common (≈70%), located at fossa ovalis
Associated with AV canal defects (Down syndrome)
Near SVC or IVC, often with abnormal pulmonary venous drainage

ATRIAL_SEPTAL_DEFECT.hemodynamics: Left-to-right shunt → increased flow to RA & RV → RV volume overload → pulmonary overcirculation → Risk of pulmonary hypertension and Eisenmenger syndrome

clinical_features.older_children: Recurrent respiratory infections, fatigue, poor weight gain

physical_exam: Wide and fixed split of 2nd heart sound (S2) – hallmark
Systolic ejection murmur at pulmonary area (↑ flow across pulmonary valve)
Mid-diastolic murmur at tricuspid area (↑ flow across tricuspid valve)

treatment.observation: Small ASD (<5 mm), may close spontaneously
treatment.surgical_repair: For primum/sinus venosus ASDs or large defects
treatment.timing: Elective closure between 2–5 years of age
treatment.post_procedure: Antiplatelet (e.g., aspirin) may be advised post device closure for 6 months

mnemonic.name: ASD HEART
expansion: H – Heart sounds: wide & fixed S2
T – Transcatheter or surgery by 5 years

VENTRICULAR_SEPTAL_DEFECT.definition: A congenital defect in the interventricular septum resulting in abnormal communication between left and right ventricles.

types.details: More common in Asians; risk of aortic valve prolapse

VENTRICULAR_SEPTAL_DEFECT.hemodynamics: Left-to-right shunt (LV → RV) → ↑ Pulmonary blood flow → Pulmonary hypertension → Risk of Eisenmenger syndrome

clinical_features.small_restrictive: Asymptomatic, loud murmur, no heart failure
clinical_features.large_nonrestrictive: CHF signs, hepatomegaly, tachypnea, recurrent LRTIs

physical_exam: Pansystolic murmur at left lower sternal border
Thrill may be palpable (in small VSDs)
Loud P2 in large VSD with pulmonary hypertension

investigations.findings: Done when PA pressures or operability is uncertain

management.observation: For small VSDs (<3 mm) – most close spontaneously within 1–2 years

surgical_device_closure.indication: Large VSD with failure to thrive
Small VSD with complications (e.g., aortic cusp prolapse)

surgical_device_closure.note: Device closure reserved for selected muscular/perimembranous types

mnemonic.name: VSD CLOSE
expansion: V – Very common congenital heart defect
D – Defect in septum (perimembranous most common)
C – CHF symptoms in large VSD

CONGENITAL_HEART_DISEASE.definition: Anatomic defects in the heart or great vessels present from birth due to abnormal embryogenesis.

investigations.utility: For complex CHDs or great vessel anomalies

initial_stabilization: Prostaglandin E1 infusion in duct-dependent cyanotic lesions
definitive_treatment: Medical follow-up (some small ASDs, VSDs, PDAs)
Palliative surgeries (e.g., BT shunt in TOF, Glenn, Fontan)

mnemonic.name: CHD FACTS
expansion: F – Failure to thrive, feeding difficulty
C – Clubbing in late cyanotic CHD
S – Screen with pulse ox at birth

PATENT_DUCTUS_ARTERIOSUS.definition: Failure of closure of the fetal ductus arteriosus within 72 hours of birth.
PATENT_DUCTUS_ARTERIOSUS.fetal_physiology: In utero: Ductus allows blood to bypass lungs; Normally closes due to ↑ oxygen and ↓ prostaglandins after birth

clinical_features.moderate: Tachypnea, poor feeding, failure to thrive
clinical_features.large: Features of CHF – breathlessness, sweating, hepatomegaly

physical_signs: Continuous "machinery" murmur at left 2nd ICS (Gibson’s murmur)

treatment.device_closure: Preferred in children >6 months with suitable anatomy
treatment.surgical_ligation: If device closure fails, symptomatic neonates, or very large PDA

mnemonic.name: PDA CLOSE
expansion: D – Ductus stays open → shunt L→R
S – Surgery if large or symptomatic

PATENT_FORAMEN_OVALE.definition: Persistent flap-like opening between atria due to failure of septum primum to fuse with septum secundum after birth (not a true septal defect).
PATENT_FORAMEN_OVALE.pathophysiology: Fetal life: Allows oxygenated blood bypass; After birth: Functional closure by ↑ LA pressure; No significant shunt unless RA pressure elevated

clinical_relevance.importance: Divers with PFO at increased risk
Rare syndrome of hypoxia worsened on sitting

diagnosis.utility: Initial test; may miss small PFOs
Gold standard for small PFO detection

management.approach: Antiplatelets (Aspirin), Anticoagulation (if DVT/PE), Device closure (select cases)

mnemonic.name: PFO FACT
expansion: F – Flap-like, not a true hole
A – Air embolism risk in divers
T – Treatment rarely needed, closure if indicated
